title: Typophile Breaks/Tunes
content:
So for those of you who haven't heard, Typophile is DJing the Saturday night "Digikana" event at TypeCon San Francisco. And while we've been doing our best to amass a pile of tunes that will please the discerning typographer, we're left with a question:   
   
What are the must-have tunes to please a Typecon crowd?   
   
Mind you, I'm not fishing for "what's your favorite song?" here - I'm looking for specific songs that mention type, alphabet, fonts, letters, etc etc. Spoken word or musical.   
   
Any links to downloadable MP3s of typographers speaking (or something similar) would also be welcome here.   
   
thanks-   
jb

 [‹ Typophile Small Talk Generator: TypeCon Edition](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.typophile.com/node/5680 "Go to previous forum topic") [Typing around Corners ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.typophile.com/node/5640 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Jared Benson

comments.content:
"The Magic Number" by De La Soul [3 Feet High & Rising]   
 [http://tinyurl.com/5ccmd](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/tinyurl.com/5ccmd)

"ABC" - The Jackson Five   
"Number Song" - DJ Shadow, from Endtroducing   
"Everyday I Write the Book" - Elvis Costello, from Punch the Clock

Very few songs have typeface names, that namecheck the title. here's two:   
   
CALEDONIA, what makes your big heart so hard?   
(Louis Jordan wrote it, but also recorded by many others)   
GEORGIA, sweet Georgia.   
(Hoagy Carmichael wrote and recorded it, Ray Charles did a classic version)   
   
How about:   
1-2-3 by Len Barry   
(Includes the line "ABC, falling in love with you was easy for me..") At least I think it does -- I haven't heard that song for 40 years!   
   
German Bold Italic by Towatei, of course.

Towa Tei - GBI (German Bold Italic)   
 [http://www.discogs.com/release/240102](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.discogs.com/release/240102)   
   
Wiliam Caslon Experience   
 [http://americanbacon.com/html/music.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/americanbacon.com/html/music.html)   
   
Futurismo Soundtrack to a Font   
 [http://www.p22.com/records/futurismo.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.p22.com/records/futurismo.html)   
(shameless plug)   
   
The sound of lettering   
 [http://www.basichip.com/tony\_schwartz/ts000.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.basichip.com/tony_schwartz/ts000.htm)

R-E-S-P-E-C-T, Give it to me! Respect, just a little bit.   
   
Aretha Franklin did the JAGUNDA hit from the Otis Redding R&B masterpiece.   
   
Also anything by the "Lettermen": "When I Fall in Love," "Theme From A Summer Place," "Put Your Head on My Shoulder," "Hurt So Bad," and "Shangri-La" (50s frathouse crooning quartet)   
 [http://www.thelettermen.com/home.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.thelettermen.com/home.html)
25 Greatest Hits

Cake - ALPHA BETA PARKING LOT - Prolonging the Magic   
   
:D

Candy Chang's seminal work, "Typography," including suchditties as "Bravo Futura" and "The Letterpress Express."   
   
 [www.redantenna.tv/candychang/audio/index.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.redantenna.tv/candychang/audio/index.htm)

La Marcha de las Vocales by "Cri Cri". Maybe not very suitable for the task.   
   
 [http://www.cri-cri.net/mp3/ca091.mp3](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.cri-cri.net/mp3/ca091.mp3)

"A" by the Barenaked Ladies, off of "Maybe You Should Drive"   
   
\< [http://www.azlyrics.com/lyrics/barenakedladies/a.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.azlyrics.com/lyrics/barenakedladies/a.html)\>

It's common knowledge that Prince has a thing for letters, especially the "U" (I Would Die 4 U, Take Me With U, U Got the Look)... he waxes melodic about letterish locales (Alphabet Street, Graffiti Bridge)... but could we expect any less from a guy who renamed himself an unpronounceable glyph?

'Ondine' by They Might Be Giants   
'Olympian' by Gene   
'Sign o the Times' by prince   
'Sale of the Century' by sleeper   
'wide open spaces' by Mansun

Any rap where they say "Word"   
 ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

I'm loving 'Alphabet Street' : )   
   
How about design from the WORD UP (say Cameo)   
   
Bit of a stretch, but 'Line up in line' by Elastica?

Sheila E and Prince's "A Love Bizarre", the hit single off   
of [Romance 1600](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B0000073RQ/qid=1089718523/sr=2-3/ref=sr_2_3/102-1301428-2341724) opens with "A, B, A B C D" instead   
of the usual "1 2 3 4". Maybe?

Don't you have a DJ friend who can put some beats under [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/images.amazon.com/images/P/B000002BO3.01.LZZZZZZZ.jpg)? ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

As electro is back in style, why not play Freeez's [I.O.U.](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B0000010HE/qid%3D1089718868/sr%3D11-1/ref%3Dsr%5F11%5F1/102-1301428-2341724)?   
It sure was a floor filler in my breakdancing days.

From my "Dope On Plastic" collection from [React](http://web.archive.org/web/20081121133422/http:/www.react-music.co.uk/home.html)

Maybe off-topic, but it is gorgeous:   
Breezin' by George Benson.

Lissenup, I'm gonna check my CD collection at home tonight   
and get back to you. Give me a little time tho (600+ CD's).
"Feel like a number", good rock by Bob Seger.

The Fish Cheer, by Country Joe and the Fish (it's the intro to Feel Like I'm Fixin' To Die Rag: "Gimme an F...")   
D-I-V-O-R-C-E, by Tammy Wynette (kinda goes with R-E-S-P-E-C-T?)   
   
Tea for Two, by Tony Bennett (Picture U upon my knee, just T 4 2 and 2 4 T")   
   
I kern C for miles, by the Who   
I shot the serif, by Bob Marley

contains samples cut up in such a way they become separate letters.   
Killer hip hop track.

I vote for this song!

i was ashamed that i had nothing to contribute, but luckily for me stuart forgot this one:   
   
"friend is a four-letter word" by cake

Something Spanish (and I mean Spain): "Carta de Amor" by Los Manolos (on their "Pasion Condal").   
It's a reading of a love letter where they speak out the punctuation too. It's sort of a loungy track (they specialize in Spanish-Sinatra-style, actually), but pretty cool, I think. I can bring the CD with me if you like.   
   
hhp

& The Boxtops.

What about some School House Rock, Grammar rock in particular. _Unpack your Adjectives, Interjections!_   
   
Anyone have a copy of SHR _Rocks_?
I do. And it does.
